text: I always knew I was different than the
other voice but it wasn't actually until
I was just a little bit older my father
insisted when I went to secondary school
that I play American football and it's
actually out there on the football field
that I realized I was playing for the
wrong team
[Music]
what's interesting is how quickly people
start to presume that you don't know the
math behind your own work and I'm always
taken aback by that strange presumption
which I will frankly say I never
experienced before and I never see my
male peers go through which is that
maybe I'm good at leading science
projects but surely I don't know the
technical details and it kind of came
out of nowhere
that just overnight people stopped
asking me math questions
when Joe and Joan are doing the same
quality of work what extra work this
Joan need to do to get the same chance
of a promotion what we found was Joan
needs to go to more prominent schools
for longer periods of time
here in the states paying those extra
tuitions not earning salaries they need
to spend longer at lower ranked jobs
there really is a monetary tax opposed
on women and in the tech industry in the
u.s. that's roughly a quarter of a
million dollars it's a tax applied to
you simply because you don't fit the
norm it's the tax on being different
